recode to decompose original WALS voicing contrast variable into two variables -- the first capturing voicing distinctions in plosives, the second capturing voicing distinctions in fricatives (if fricatives present). The decomposition generally is motivated in the corresponding WALS chapter.

recode to decompose original WALS rhythmic stress variable into three variables -- the first capturing the presence of rhythmic stress at all, the second capturing the presence of trochaic rhythmic stress (if rhythmic stress present), the third capturing the presence of iambic rhythmic stress (if rhythmic stress present). The decomposition generally is motivated in the corresponding WALS chapter.

recode to decompose original WALS fixed stress variable into three variables -- the first capturing the presence of fixed stress at all, the second capturing the specific location of fixed stress if it is left-leaning (if fixed stress present), the third capturing the specific location of fixed stress if it is right-leaning (if fixed stress present). The decomposition regarding the first variable is motivated in the WALS chapter, the creation of the second and third variables enables logical independence, given the conjunction of all variables, and makes use of the distinction between left- and right-headed stress outlined in the chapter.

recode to decompose original WALS case affix position variable into two variables -- the first tracking the position but not fusion of case markers (if morphological case present), the second tracking fusion but not position of case markers (if morphological case present) -- note that neither variable is merged with corresponding autotyp variables, because autotyp case marking includes pronominal case and WALS does not. The decomposition generally is motivated in the corresponding WALS chapter.

recode to decompose original WALS occuring of nominal plurality variable into two variables -- the first to track obligatoriness vs. optionality of plural coding, excluding the state "All nouns, optional in inanimates" because these languages treat plural obligatoriness differently on an animacy split (if nominal plurals present), the second tracking whether only human or all nouns receive plurality (if nominal plurals present). The decomposition is motivated in the corresonding WALS chapter

recode to decompose original WALS occuring of plurality in independent personal pronouns into four variables -- the first to track number-sensitivity of personal pronouns, the second to track whether or not pronominal person and number are expressed combined (if pronouns number-sensitive), the third to track whether plural is morphologically marked on the pronoun (if pronouns number-sensitive) and the fourth to track whether the marker is a special pronominal marker or the same as for the nominal plural (if plural is morphologcially marked on the pronoun and there is nominal plural). The decomposition generally is motivated in the corresponding WALS chapter.

recode to decompose original WALS associative plural variable into two variables -- the first to track the presence of associative plurals, the second to track whether the associative plural is unique or the same as the additive plural (if associative plurals present). Note that further decomposing the variable to distinguish between "Unique affixal associative plural" and "Unique periphrastic associative plural" is not possible (<100 languages once conditioned). The decomposition generally is motivated in the corresponding WALS chapter.

recode to decompose original WALS negative morpheme and verb order variable into three variables -- the first to track the order between negative affix and verb, the second to track the order between the negative word and the verb, the third to track wheter there is double negation (enriched with the corresponding autotyp variable, prioritising WALS in cases of conflict because it is coded for more languages), the fourth to track whether double negation is obligatory or optional (if there is double negation) -- negative affixes and negative words are considered separately because affixes and words are subject to different pressures. The decomposition generally is motivated in the corresponding WALS chapter.

recode to decompose original WALS (a)symmetric standard negation variable into two variables -- the first to track the presence of asymmetric standard negation, the second to track whether the language only partially or fully displays asymmetric negation (if asymmetric standard negation present). The decomposition generally is motivated in the corresponding WALS chapter.

recode to decompose original WALS subtypes of asymmetric negation variable into two variables -- the first to track the presence of the finite-type of asymmetric negation (if asymmetric negation present), the second to track the presence of the non-real subtype of asymmetric negation (if asymmetric negation present) -- Finiteness and NonReal represent cohesive states, while ACat lumps the remaining asymmetric cases, as described in the corresponding chapter. The presence of the AFin and ANonReal is thus tracked independently for the languages that do display asymmetric negation, but not for ACat.

recode to decompose original WALS definite article variable into four variables -- the first to track the presence of articles at all (definite or indefinite), the second to track the presence of definite articles (if articles present) at all, the third to track the type of definite articles (if definite articles present), merging the states "Definite word distinct from demonstrative" and "Definite affix", the fourth to track whether definite articles are expressed as words or affixes (if definite articles present). The decomposition generally is motivated in the corresponding WALS chapter.

recode to decompose original WALS indefinite article variable into two variables -- the first to track the presence of indefinite articles (if articles present) at all, the second to track the type of indefinite articles (if indefinite articles present), mergeing the states "Indefinite word distinct from 'one'" and "Indefinite affix", the third to track whether indefinite articles are expressed as words or affixes (if indefinite articles present)

recode to decompose original WALS distributive numerals variable into two variables -- the first to track the presence of distributive numerals at all, the second to track the morphological means of marking distributive numerals (if distributive numerals present). Note that further decomposition into a third variable tracking position of distributive numeral cannot be created (< 100 languages once conditioned). The decomposition generally is motivated in the corresponding WALS chapter.

recode to decompose original WALS overall suffixing-prefixing variable into two variables -- the first to track tendencies towards little or no inflectional morphology vs. extensive inflectional morphology (this variable interacts with some autotyp variables on case, tense marking etc, which have a no morphology state, but it is much more inclusive/holistic and coded for many more languages. Also, it probably interacts with other variables where inflectional morphology is presupposed), the second to track overall tendencies towards suffixing vs. prefixing (if extensive inflectional morphology), excluding the mixed/intermediate state "equally suffixing and prefixing". This decomposition is motivated in the WALS chapter. The variable is not further decomposed by creating sub-variables tracking the extent of suffixation and prefixation respectively, because the cut-offs are arbitrary. Note that 9 elements contribute to the prefixing/suffixing index of WALS 26 (variable rec_dca_WALS_26A_2). However, no statistical expectations were formulated as there are many different ways that a language would be characterized as primarily prefixing or suffixing according to WALS 26 and there is no clear expectation of some elements contributing to the affixation index being more important than others. Instead, prefixing/suffixing is logged as a known network of remaining dependencies

recode to decompose original WALS negative morphemes variable into two variables -- the first to track the fusion of negation, creating the states affix, word and tone by merging the variable with the relevant states another WALS variable (if no obligatory double negation), the second to track whether a negative word is an auxiliary or a particle (if negative morpheme is expressed as word). Decomposition is motivated in the corresponding WALS chapter.

recode to decompose original WALS nonperiphrastic causative variable into three variables -- the first to track the presence of non-periphrastic causative constructions, the second to track the presence of morphological causative constructions (merged with the autotyp variable tracking the presence of causative inflection on the fully inflected verb for the positive state) (if non-periphrastic causative constructions present), and the third to track the presence of compound causative constructions (if non-periphrastic causative constructions present). The decomposition generally is motivated in the corresponding WALS chapter.

recode to decompose original WALS action nominals variable into two variables -- the first to track the presence of action nominals, the second to track the type of action nominal present, excluding the mixed/intermediate state "Mixed" and the inconsistent state "Other" and pooling together all possessive states due to their involvement of possessive marking (if action nominals present). Note that further decomposition of different types of possessive states is not possible (<100 languages once conditioned).

recode to decompose original WALS morphological imperative variable into three variables -- the first to track the presence of a morphological second-person imperative, the second to track whether the second person is number-neutral or not (if second-person imperative present), the third to track the number of second-person imperative (if second-person imperative present and number distinctions exist) -- note that we do not track 2nd singular and 2nd plural in separate variables but omit the state "Second plural" in the third variable instead, since it only includes two languages.

recode to decompose original WALS prohibitive variable into two variables -- the first to distinguish between normal and special types of imperative used in prohibitives, the second to distinguish between normal and special types of negatives used in prohibitives. The decomposition generally is motivated in the corresponding WALS chapter.

recode to decompose original WALS past tense variable into two variables -- the first to capture the presence of past tense (if tense present), the second to capture whether or not past tense encompasses remoteness distinctions (if past tense present) -- note that further decomposing the variable into the number of remoteness distinctions present is not possible (< 100 languages once conditioned). The decomposition generally is motivated in the corresponding WALS chapter.

recode to decompose original WALS nominal and verbal conjunction variable into two variables -- the first to capture the identity/differentiation of nominal and verbal conjunction, the second to track whether nominal/verbal conjunction are expressed via juxtaposition (if identically expressed). The decomposition generally is motivated in the corresponding WALS chapter.

recode to decompose original WALS want complement subject variable into three variables -- the first to track the use of desideratives in "want" complement subjects, the second to track languages leaving the subject implicit (if no desiderative), the third to track those expressing it explicitly (if no desiderative). Further decomposition into expression of desideratives is not possible (<100 languages once conditioned). The decomposition generally is motivated in the corresponding WALS chapter.

recode to decompose original WALS zero marking variable into two variables - the first to track the presence/absence of 3rd person zero marking (if verbal agreement/S-person marking for some person present), the second to track whether zero occurs in all 3rd person forms or in 3rd sg forms only (if zero marking in the 3rd person present) -- regarding the second variable: note that we omit the state "Zero only in 3rd nonsingular", since it only includes one language. Note that further decomposition distinguishing between all or some 3rd singular forms allowing for zero marking is not possible (<100 languages once conditioned). The decomposition generally is motivated in the corresponding WALS chapter.

recode to decompose original WALS oblique relativization variable into two variables - the first to track whether oblique relativization is present the second to track the type of relativization strategy used (if there is relativization on obliques). The decomposition generally is motivated in the corresponding WALS chapter.

recode to decompose original WALS pronominal possessive affix variable into two variables -- the first to track the presence of possessive affixes, the second to track whether possessive affixes are primarily expressed as prefixes or primarily expressed as sufffixes (if possessive affixes present) -- note that the state none primary is undeterminable, since the other states are not tracking the presence of prefixes or suffixes generally but explicitly tracking whether prefixes or suffixes are primary -- note that prefixing/suffixing of pronominal possessive affixes is included even if it participates as one of many secondary features contributing to generally prefixing vs. generally suffixing languages (rec_dca_WALS_26A_2). This variable cannot be used to enrich o_autotyp_LocusOfMarkingPerLanguage_HasHeadMarkingForPOSS because "No possessive affixes" can mean different things: either that there are possessive clitics, or that there is dependent marking rather than head marking. Also, in case of different possession classes, if at least one uses possessive affixes, then the language is categorized according to this class. Finally, even the TRUE state cannot be used as there are languages without head marking in nominal possession that have pronominal affixes in pronominal possession.

recode to decompose original WALS person marking on adpositions variable into two variabes -- the first to track the presence of adpositions (note that this variable is created by merging WALS_48A with WALS_85A, with Dryer's (85A) variable prioritised in case of mismatch because his definition is more inclusive and because his variable is coded for more languages), the second to track whether person marking on adpositions is possible (if adpositions present), the third to track whether adposition person marking can occur on nouns or only on pronouns (if person marking on adpositions possible)

WALS categorizes partial reduplication as prefix or suffix depending on which syllable is reduplicated, while autotyp merges partial and complete reduplication. In order to preserve the maximum number of reduplicative strategies, autotyp is prioritised for coding for this variable despite WALS being coded for more languages. However, even after this prioritization, there could still be languages that use partial reduplication that are categorized under "concatenative" in the recoded variable due to them being coded as such in WALS and not coded at all in autotyp), the second to track position (prefix vs. suffix) of nominal plurals (merged with the autotyp variable tracking the position of plural markers -- note that infixes, circumfixes or split markers (from autotyp) are not considered to ensure compatibility with WALS, prioritising WALS, which is coded for more languages) (if nominal plural concatenative). recode to decompose original WALS absence of common consonants variable into three variables -- the first to track whether bilabials are present (merged with data from PHOIBLE, prioritising PHOIBLE in cases of conflict, because it is coded for substantially more languages), the second to track whether fricatives are present (merged with data from PHOIBLE, prioritising PHOIBLE in cases of conflict, because it is coded for substantially more languages), the third to track whether nasals are present (merged with data from PHOIBLE, prioritising PHOIBLE in cases of conflict, because it is coded for substantially more languages). recode to decompose original WALS presence of uncommon consonants variable into four variables -- the first to track whether clicks are present (merged with data from PHOIBLE, prioritising PHOIBLE in cases of conflict, because it is coded for substantially more languages), the second to track whether labial-velars are present (merged with data from PHOIBLE – note that here, data from WALS is prioritised because the PHOIBLE variable tracks Irish as FALSE (Irisih has a bˠ and a pˠ)), the third to track whether pharyngeals are present (merged with data from PHOIBLE, prioritising PHOIBLE in cases of conflict, because it is coded for substantially more languages) (if fricatives present), the fourth to track whether interdental fricatives/affricates are present (merged with data from PHOIBLE, prioritising PHOIBLE in cases of conflict, because it is coded for substantially more languages) (if fricatives present). Note that the state "Prominence", which is heterogeneous according to the chapter, is not tracked separately, and that the state "Combined" cannot be attributed to any states. recode to decompose original WALS voicing and gaps in plosive variable into two variables -- the first to track whether there is a voicing gap in plosives for bilabials with /p/ (or /p/ and /g/) missing in an otherwise complete system with /ptkbdg/, the second to track whethere there is a voicing gap in plosives for velars with /g/ (or /p/ and /g/) missing in an otherwise complete system with /ptkbdg/. Note that the "Other" state is heterogeneous by definition and also very common and cannot be taken into account for either of the subvariables. Decomposition is motivated in the corresponding WALS chapter - we opt for decomposing in favor of missing /p/, /g/ specifically rather than opposing a compete /ptkbdg/ system to any gap, because the latter way of decomposition would not only include the populous and heterogeneous "other" states, but also the complete /ptkbdg/ state which is also heterogeneous (it does not include full plosive inventories, but only inventories that include /ptkbdg/ (e.g. an inventory without bilabial segments at all, would be categorized as "other", as would an inventory without a voicing contrast in its plosives at all).

expectation.tested: finger and toe colexified XOR finger and hand colexified
motivation.for.test: Humans have bilateral symmetry and four limbs. We expect the way people colexify one set of limbs (e.g. arms, upper) to correlate with colexification in the other (e.g. legs, lower). We also don't think a language will have one term for the entire appendage (e.g., shoulder to fingertips, hip to toetips) so have hypothesized that colexification will not include the whole limb. We also expect colexifications not to extend across upper and lower limbs, e.g. finger-toe colexification should not coincide with toe-foot colexification (where fingers, toes, and feet are the same). Finally, if colexifications within parts of limbs are present, we expect them to not have incompatible patterns between upper and lower limbs (e.g. leg and foot colexification should not coexist with hand and finger colexification).
